This document provides guidelines and requirements for deploying the Blue Planet products.
This guide describes how to prepare the environment for deploying the Blue Planet platform and solutions.

You can deploy the Blue Planet platform and solutions on your own server and within your enterprise’s IT infrastructure (termed as an on-premises deployment), or you can deploy platform and solutions on a supported cloud platform which includes Amazon AWS, Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud Platform.

This guide separately discusses the requirements for deploying Blue Planet products on any of the these platforms. Currently, this guide covers the requirements for deploying the following solutions and the combination of solutions:
Customers and professional services can use this document to understand the requirements for installing the Blue Planet products and plan the installation accordingly.

header: Introduction to deploying Blue Planet products

content.text: You can deploy Blue Planet products using the Blue Planet native platform, or using the Kubernetes open source container orchestration platform. While the platform remains same for all the products, the solution varies for each product.
content.header: Introduction to deploying Blue Planet products

content.text: When you deploy Blue Planet products using the Blue Planet native platform, you use the Blue Planet installer (bpi) to deploy the Blue Planet platform and a lineup file to deploy the Blue Planet product. The lineup files are either compressed in a .tar file or these are available online. Before you begin the deployment procedure, you download or avail the required installation files. These files include Blue Planet Installer script, lineup files, among other required files.
content.header: Introduction to deploying Blue Planet products

content.text: You can deploy the Blue Planet platform and solutions on:
content.header: Introduction to deploying Blue Planet products
Introduction to deploying Blue Planet products
Introduction to deploying Blue Planet products

content.text: You can also deploy Blue Planet products using the Kubernetes platform, which means that you use Kubernetes infrastructure (a combination of resources including servers, physical or virtual machines, cloud platforms and more) to deploy your products.
content.header: Introduction to deploying Blue Planet products

content.text: Kubernetes is an open source container orchestration platform that automates many of the manual processes involved in deploying, managing, and scaling containerized applications. You can cluster together groups of nodes running containers, and Kubernetes helps you easily and efficiently manage those clusters.
content.header: Introduction to deploying Blue Planet products

content.text: Currently, you can deploy your solutions on the following Kubernetes cluster orchestration platforms provided by different cloud providers:
content.header: Introduction to deploying Blue Planet products
Introduction to deploying Blue Planet products

header: Licensing requirement and setting up license server

content.text: Beginning with the 20.10 release, all Blue Planet products require the use of a license server. Be sure to include this requirement in your hardware plans, and follow the instructions in this guide to ensure you set up and use the license server.
content.header: Licensing requirement and setting up license server

content.text: To deploy 22.08 version of BPO, BPI and ROA, you must procure Ciena license to extract the deployment files from the tar files you download from the Ciena portal.
content.header: Licensing requirement and setting up license server
Licensing requirement and setting up license server
Licensing requirement and setting up license server

content.text: Before you deploy your Blue Planet software, ensure that you have the licenses you need. You need a license to extract the software from the tar files you downloaded from the Ciena portal, and you need licenses to run the software application and add-ons.
During the License Server setup procedure, you will associate the licenses with your license server and load the licenses.
The following table list the licenses to extract the software.
The following tables list the licenses to run the software application.
BP APPLICATION MDSO GEO REDUNDANCY LICENSE
BP APPLICATION NFVO GEO REDUNDANCY LICENSE
BP ADD-ON APPLICATION BANDWIDTH ON DEMAND LICENSE
BP ADD-ON APPLICATION 5G NETWORK SLICING LICENSE
BP ADD-ON APPLICATION API ADAPTATION LAYER LICENSE
BP ADD-ON SINGLE TMF 633 PLUGIN LICENSE
BP ADD-ON SINGLE TMF 638 PLUGIN LICENSE
The following BPI components require licensing.
Guided Operation, main menu GO context menu items. REST end points.

section of External License Server Documentation
You can deploy solutions in either a single-host configuration (for smaller networks) or a multi-host configuration (for larger networks).

A single-host configuration consists of 1 host at a site. This type of configuration does not support any redundancy and fault tolerance capability, because if the host goes down, the entire service stops until the host becomes up and running.
A multi-host configuration consists of multiple hosts at the same site, where all nodes in the cluster are active by default.

If solutions are deployed in multi-host mode, it is recommended that the cluster has at least three nodes. To users of a solution user interface (UI) and northbound API clients, this multi-host configuration looks like a single logical unit. It is accessed using a virtual Site IP address. This Site IP address redirects requests to the appropriate node in the cluster.

You can design your multi-host cluster configuration in such a way that ensures availability and continuity of services to users, irrespective of a network disaster. There can be several reasons of a network disaster, such as, power outage, network breakdown, configuration issues, among others.
To recover from a disaster in real-time, Blue Planet supports following recovery options:

HA provides capabilities that allow a site’s primary functionality to remain operational in response to a failure of a component on that site. Blue Planet achieves this continuity of service through redundant or fault-tolerant components on supported server clusters.
In the Blue Planet HA deployment, Blue Planet software runs across a cluster of hosts in a site, rather

If one of the hosts in the cluster goes down, requests are redirected to other working hosts. However, users are not aware of this hosts switching activity, and they continue performing their operations without any interruption.
In order for HA to function properly, it is required that:

Geographic Redundancy is the replication of your data in two geographically separate and interconnected sites (Active and Standby) to ensure that your data remains intact and is always available if a disaster happens. In the case of a disaster, your applications immediately switch from the impacted site to the redundant or standby site.

The two sites communicate using secure IPsec tunnels. Clients connect to the Active site which actively manages the network and maintains sessions to the managed devices. All data hosted on the active site is continuously and automatically replicated to the Standby site. Therefore, if a disaster happens at the active site, the standby site takes over the control and becomes the primary active site and starts providing seamless uninterrupted services to the users.
For more information about the GR deployment, refer to the admin guide for Blue Planet products.

Blue Planet Inventory (BPI) does not support horizontal scaling by adding hosts in a multi-host configuration. Larger networks, user communities, and transactional loads are handled by vertically scaling the host(s) deployed.
The following sizes are presented as guidance for sizing BPI servers:

BPI uses a graph database to store the inventory data. To ensure the operation efficiency of the database, it is important to tune the graph memory parameters to efficiently use the available platform. The recommended initial settings are listed in the following table:

header: Regions and Availability Zones in cloud

content.text: Regions are separate geographic areas that cloud servicer providers use to house its infrastructure. These regions are distributed around the world to enable customers to choose a region closest to them for hosting their cloud infrastructure. The closer is a region to you, the quicker is the service delivery for you, with reduced network latency.
content.header: Regions and Availability Zones in cloud

content.text: An Availability Zone (AZ) consists of multiple data centers connected to each other over redundant low latency private network links. Each region typically has multiple AZs. These AZs are inter-connected and communicate with each other continuously over redundant low-latency network links.
content.header: Regions and Availability Zones in cloud

content.text: So, if you design your infrastructure to have backups of data in other AZs, you build a very efficient model of resiliency and distributed computing, the core concepts of cloud computing.
content.header: Regions and Availability Zones in cloud

content.text: For example, if you distribute your instances across multiple Availability Zones and one instance fails, you can design your application such that an instance in another Availability Zone can handle service requests, ensuring high availability, resiliency, fault-tolerance, and scalability.
content.header: Regions and Availability Zones in cloud

content.text: Following GR deployment scenarios are supported for deployment of Blue Planet products:
The GR is not supported for deployment of Blue Planet products on Kubernetes. Only the HA support on a minimum 3-node cluster deployment is available currently.

In this multi-host configuration scenario, the deployment is performed in a single AZ within a Region, with active and standby are configured in the same region. This type of deployment does ensures local redundancy, but does not always ensure service continuity, because, if the whole Region goes down, the entire service stops until the Region is recovered from disaster successfully.

In this multi-host configuration scenario, the deployment is done in a single AZ across multiple Regions. This deployment scenario is more resilient and stable than the previous one. If one Region fails, the other configured Region starts providing services.

In this multi-host configuration scenario, the deployment is done across multiple AZs and multiple Regions, and the deployment of different solution components is distributed across multiple AZs, So, the service delivery continues even of an Az within the primary region fails or the whole region fails.

This deployment scenario is the most resilient, stable, fault-tolerant, and secure. However, it may have performance issues due to the latency in communication between cluster hosts, which will impact processes like load-sharing, load-balancing.

header: Server hardware and VM requirements for on-premises deployment

content.text: Logging from applications and services to syslog
Docker images (defaults to the unallocated disk space in the root volume group)
The total disk space required for installing BPI should at least 1TB for production and 500GB for lab.

header: Supported operating systems for on-premises deployment

content.text: You can install the Blue Planet platform and solutions on any of the following operating systems:
content.header: Supported operating systems for on-premises deployment
Supported operating systems for on-premises deployment

content.text: Installing Blue Planet platform and solution requires one of the supported operating systems with the Infrastructure Server package.
Throughout this procedure, "OS" refers to the supported RHEL and CentOS releases listed above.
Ciena requires that the OS Infrastructure Server package be based on the baseline ISO DVD image for each release. Installing an updated Infrastructure Server package is not supported.

During the OS installation, you choose options that facilitate the installation and operations. If the OS is already installed, review the installation steps to ensure the selected options are provisioned on your host. If you have any questions, contact Ciena Customer Support.
This is an example. Modify the steps to fit your OS media.
sudo dd if=</path to image>.iso of=/dev/disk4 bs=4096
Ensure that all the hosts are assigned a unique hostname in case of multi host deployment
The system automatically detects the live network interface for Network & Host Name.
